Comment: In the first round I was black against  Paweł Pityński, 1485, the tournament organiser, who I had beaten when I played in the same tournament in April. Playing black I developed an attack on his king, which was wandering round the king-side. I forced him to sacrifice a pawn and the exchange. But he got back into it. He had a winning position, but we both became short of time and we reached an opposite coloured bishops ending which probably was drawn. So I wanted to win this one.
Incidentally this was reconstructed after the game. I think I have done it accurately, but it is possible that the move order is not correct.
So I also decided to develop my queen-side bishop outside the pawn chain. Looking at the opening database now, I see that Qb3 is more commonly played, and scores better. That is on its way...
So that if he takes on c4 I can recapture immediately with my bishop.
I am happy to exchange my "bad" bishop on the same coloured squares as my central pawns.
He avoids the exchange. I see on the databases that black has played BxBd3, dxc4 or Bg6 in this position. This seems to be a new move, according to the limited Gameknot databases.
